text: Hello, this is the Global News Podcast from the BBC World Service,
with reports and analysis from across the world, the latest news seven days a week.
BBC World Service podcasts are supported by advertising.
You know, in life, no matter how much you are down, if you are willing to
give your best in fight, you know, you can always have a fighting chance to come back.
We had to rise from the ashes.
Search for amazing sports stories wherever you get your BBC podcasts.
The US for a Ukrainian missile attack on occupied Crimea, which left at least four people dead.
And Saudi Arabia says more than 1,300 pilgrims died during this year's march.
Also in the podcast, French women march against the far right National Rally.
I'm here because I'm a woman and I don't want my rights to be taken from me because some far
rights movement wants to take the power in France.
And we'll once again welcome a new pair of giant pandas to the Smithsonian's National Zoo
and Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, DC.
Pandemonium in the US, get it?
Sparked by China's offer of two new bears.
But we begin in the Russian Republic of Dagestan.
Gunmen opening fire on a street in the regional capital, Mahashkala.
It was one of two cities in the mainly Muslim region, which came under attack.
In WN, 125 kilometers south along the Caspian Sea, a synagogue and an Orthodox Church were
attacked and set on fire. A second Orthodox Church and a police checkpoint were also targeted.
As we record this podcast, the authorities say at least 10 people were killed,
mostly police officers, but including a Russian Orthodox priest.
In Mahashkala, people fled in panic from a beach while there were also reports of
gunmen attacking a police car in a village.
I've got more details about the assault from Famiel Ismailov from the BBC Russian service.
Well, we know that the authorities announced that the active phase of counter-terrorist
separation, as they call it, has now finished.
But they still keep the roads leading out of Mahashkala completely locked down.
The cities are locked down. They're looking for any possible
attackers and people who were associated with them.
But we definitely know that six attackers had been killed, four in Mahashkala, two in Derband.
And we know that at least 10 people are dead, a date of them, police officers and 25 injured.
They shoot out at the village that you mentioned.
That is probably the reports about the apprehension of a local official from that village.
Someone called Magamet Amaru.
Apparently, and that's what the reports say, his two sons and nephew were among the fighters
attacking the churches and synagogues.
Yeah, I mean, so these were what coordinated attacks and do we know who by?
It sounds like they're absolutely coordinated.
They basically started absolutely at the same time.
The question of who's behind it is a very difficult one, because we definitely don't know
who was organizing that attack.
However, last October, when Hamas attacked Israel, the strange riots happened in Mahashkala
International Airport, because somebody spread the rumor that apparently Jewish
settlers' refugees are coming to Mahashkala.
And the riots have started and men of fighting age men have taken over the building of the
airport, even the airfield.
And police was unable to do anything.
So the fact that there is an undercurrent that we don't know exactly,
the Islamist kind of undercurrent, that we don't know exactly how it operates,
where it comes from, probably still exists there.
And of course, this region, Dagestan bordering Chechnya, has a history of violence.
Will it be worrying the authorities in Moscow?
Absolutely, because what happened in the 90s when Chechnya was
so spread violence from Chechnya to Dagestan as well, it was the clash of two kinds of Islam.
Dagestan is a conservative Muslim country, that's correct.
But Islam practiced there, is Sufi Islam, much more peaceful and more meditative.
The Islam practicing Chechnya was and is a Vahab Islam, and much more radical.
So we can see that there is a possible clash within Dagestan itself,
that could also spread over into other Islamic republics of northern Caucasus.
And that definitely should be worrying, though it is in Moscow.
Familish Mylov of the BBC Russian Service.
Meanwhile, Russia says the United States is responsible for a Ukrainian attack on occupied
Crimea, which killed at least four people, including three children.
The Russian Defense Ministry said the Black Sea port of Sevastopol,
which Moscow annexed in 2014, was targeted by U.S. supplied attackums missiles,
one of which exploded above a beach.
Julian Marshall got the details from our security correspondent,
Gordon Carrera in Kiev.
What we know comes from Russian officials, who have said that a number of these attackum
missiles were fired, and that four were intercepted by their air defenses,
but they say one-a-fifth detonated mid-air, and then rained down shrapnel, they say,
on a beach at Sevastopol, leading to over a hundred wounded, they say, and the number dead.
Not likely to have been the intended target, more likely a military target,
a base perhaps nearby.
And this is the first time that Ukraine has used these attackum missiles on Crimea?
No, what's I think significant is these are an important tool in their armory, as they see it,
because they have the ability to go much longer range than some of the other weapon systems,
up to 300 kilometres, which from the Ukrainian point of view,
allows them to hit deeper behind Russian lines, in particularly supply lines, bases,
and Crimea has been one of the targets.
I think what's significant is the Russians are blaming the US, saying that it was US specialists
who programmed the coordinates for these missiles, using US satellite data,
as well as the weapons themselves, having been US supplied, and then saying from the Russian foreign
ministry that they will be raising this in the international community.
Could I just turn to Hakeif, a city in northeast Ukraine, which has come under Russian attack
for the second day in a row?
Yes, that's right. Another attack from Russian glide bombs on Hakeif. Yesterday,
those glide bombs hit some manufacturing facilities and a residential building,
killing a woman who'd just got off a trolley bus. Today it looks like an educational building
was hit with more casualties. So part of what seems to be a sustained campaign
against that city, which is close to where the Russians have been trying to push down
in the last month or so militarily. So it looks like part of that wider offensive is to try and
put pressure on the city. And more broadly, we've seen the Russian aerial attacks targeting
civilian infrastructure, particularly in terms of the energy infrastructure, across Ukraine as well,
which has led to the Ukrainians calling for more air defences.
Haven't the Ukrainians been given permission by the United States to use those US-supplied
long-range missiles to attack inside Russia in the vicinity of Hakeif? Has that happened yet?
The Americans were reluctant to allow those weapons to be used over the border into Russia
because they were concerned that that could be seen as an escalatory step. But the US confirmed
recently that it would allow those, particularly I think the concern was that around that Hakeif
area, because of the Russian advances around a month ago, that there was a danger of a kind of
serious pushback of Ukrainian defences. The concern was it's quite close to the border there,
that to be able to deal with the supply lines and the Russian forces building up,
that they needed to be able to attack over the border. So yes, the permission was given by the US.
Gordon Carrera in Kiyev talking to Julian Marshall. The Israeli military has admitted that its
soldiers violated operating procedures when they tied a wounded Palestinian man to a military
vehicle during a raid in the occupied West Bank. Israel said he was a suspect who was wounded in
an exchange of fire in Janin and was eventually transferred to the Red Crescent. The West Bank,
the larger of the two Palestinian territories, has seen an upsurge in violence since the war in Gaza
began. The Israeli defence minister, Yev Gant, is currently visiting the US to discuss the conflict
with Hamas, as well as tensions with the Lebanese group Hezbollah. I spoke about that to our
correspondent in Jerusalem, Sebastian Usher, but first I asked him what do people in Israel make
of the video showing the man strapped to a jeep? To be honest, I haven't seen a huge reaction to
it in Israel. There's been more reaction to some of the more aggressive behaviour by the police
in Israel itself on Saturday night when they were dealing with the latest anti-government protests
and demonstrators demanding that the Netanyahu government do all it can to get the remaining
hostages out. There's been a lot about that. There's a piece from an Israeli newspaper,
the Jerusalem Post, it expresses a viewpoint that would be shared, I think, by many,
essentially saying the UN Special Rapporteur Francesca Albanese accused the idea of using
this Palestinian man as a human shield. Now, the reaction in the Jerusalem Post and its editorial
is to say that this is completely ridiculous and unfair since it's Hamas, which uses human
shields. And as we know, this has been an accusation that the Israeli military
V is ready government has made about Hamas for years and years, but specifically in the context
of the current conflict in Gaza where the government officials have said that Hamas
essentially is responsible for civilian casualties in Gaza as Israel tries to target senior Hamas
commanders and fighters by positioning the sites where they are sheltering, hiding out
however you want to put it close to where civilians are. So essentially saying that it's Hamas
who uses human shields. But I mean, again, this is a very, very bad negative image for Israel to
go around the world. This video has gone viral. If you take away the accusation that potentially
the man was being used as a human shield, the way that he's described his treatment, his family as
well is pretty extreme. I mean, he had been wounded and he says that he was basically waiting
for ambulances for one to two hours. And then was man-hand and thrust up onto this
truck and bound to it in the heat of the day. So he had the metal burning into him as well.
So he says that the injuries are already sustained were made much worse by this.
And not ideal for these images to be beamed around the world as the Israeli Defense Minister is in
Washington. Yes. I mean, he is there, Joav Galant, to speak to his counterpart, senior
U.S. officials about where not just the conflict in Gaza, but potentially a widening and a bigger
conflict opening up on Israel's northern border with Hezbollah and Lebanon itself,
where that might go. There's been a lot of rhetoric from both sides in the past week or two,
which has really raised huge concern that after Gaza, Lebanon may be next in the sites of the
Israeli army, and the Israeli government. Sebastian Asher in Jerusalem.
The government of Saudi Arabia has given the first official death toll for this year's
Harge pilgrimage to Mecca, which took place during an extreme heat wave.
Pilgrims that register with the authorities can take advantage of facilities like air
condition tents and official Harge transport, but nearly half a million of the pilgrims were
not on authorized trips. Yousif Taha has the details. The Saudi Health Minister, Faj al-Jalaj al
said that 1,301 pilgrims had lost their lives, with 83% of them being unregistered.
Mr. Al-Jalaj al-Sedli had walked long distances in searing heat, which at times exceeded 50 degrees
Celsius, with no shelter, while many were elderly with long-term illnesses. Saudi Arabia has been
criticized for not doing more to make the Harge safer, especially for unregistered pilgrims,
who have no access to facilities such as air condition tents and official Harge transport.
Yousif Taha. Last year, China took back its pandas from the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington,
D.C., believing the city without any for the first time since 1972. But two more pandas are on their
way. They should arrive by the end of the year. Toby Luckhurst reports from the U.S. Capitol on
the mounting excitement. We'll once again welcome a new pair of giant pandas to the Smithsonian's
National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, D.C.
Pandas have been at D.C.'s zoos in 1972, when the Chinese gifted a pair to President Richard Nixon's
wife, Pat. Potentions are high between Washington and Beijing, and D.C.'s pandas were returned to
China in November of 2023. The announcement of two new bears came last month in a slick marketing
video, featuring First Lady Dr. Jill Biden. We can't wait to celebrate this historic moment
here in our nation's Capitol. Join us. It's official. The pandas are coming back to D.C.
You might be able to hear some building work behind me, where they're preparing for the arrival
of the new pandas. There are banners all over the place screaming, the pandas are coming,
big block letters. I love a line at the end of 2020.
And there's already a ton of merchandise in the shops here.
I can see it. Mugs, t-shirts, necklaces, building blogs, magnets, toys, obviously.
Hoodies, I mean anything you could possibly imagine with a panda on it. It looks like very good business
for the zoo. I'm sure they can make a lot of money through their merchandise. But of course,
it's very good business for the Chinese. The pandas are out on loan. They're not kept forever
in the U.S. The Smithsonian revealed it will pay $1 million a year to China to fund conservation
research efforts there. So it makes a lot of sense for them to do it. And of course,
it's not just a money spinner. There's diplomacy at work as well.
Huge soft power in this. Children all over the United States love pandas now.
Dennis Wilder was a senior CIA official, but he now serves as a senior fellow at Georgetown
University here in the U.S. Capitol. The soft power has worked when China looks at how bad its
reputation is in the United States. What it's hoping for is a new generation of Americans who
are going to have a different attitude. And indeed, if you look at the polling numbers,
younger Americans have a more positive attitude of China than older Americans.
And part of it is pandas. Mr. Wilder told me that although relations between DC and Beijing
have sunk even lower over issues like the Russian invasion of Ukraine or claims in the South China
Sea, neither power sees a reason to make things worse this year. Right now, there is what I would
call uncomfortable coexistence. We are barely stable in the relationship right now. But both sides
have reason not to have it blow up in 2024. Dennis Wilder, ending that report by Toby Luckhurst.
And still to come on the Global News podcast. Yeah, I walked in and first thing was the smell.
It just smelled everything. All the weed, all the human stuff. The man whose family home was
turned into a cannabis farm.
Hi, I'm former Wales International footballer Robert Earnshaw. I'm in Copper Bullets, a new
four part series from Amazing Sport Stories. I'm exploring how my birth country Zambia
overcame the devastating loss of their national football team in 1993. Zambia has had its biggest
blow ever in the history of the country. I kept asking myself, how do we honour these people?
We had to raise from the ashes. Amazing Sport Stories from the BBC World Service.
Find it wherever you get your BBC podcasts.
There has been widespread anger on Indian social media after a crucial entrance test for postgraduate
medical courses was postponed with just hours to go. The Health Ministry called it a precautionary
measure after allegations of irregularities in cheating in other entrance tests.
And Marasan Etirajan reports,
More than 200,000 doctors had been registered to appear for Sunday's neat PG exam, nearly half of
them women. One doctor on social media said she had travelled all the way from Dubai to take
the exam and had spent more than a thousand dollars to prepare for the test. Another candidate said,
I can't put my anger into words. Does the government know how frustrating this is?
The government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi is facing severe criticism over the alleged
lack of oversight and integrity in the handling of crucial entrance exams.
On Saturday night, it sacked the head of the National Testing Agency after allegations of
irregularities in the undergraduate medical entrance exam. Opposition parties and student groups have
been holding protests across the country. South Asia regional editor Anne Barasan Etirajan.
If the polls are to be believed, France could see a seismic victory for the far right in the
upcoming parliamentary election. On Sunday, thousands of women took to the streets of Paris and other
cities to voice their opposition to Marine Le Pen's National Rally. One of those who took part was
Shirley Warden of the French Communist Party. We are witnessing a comeback to an archaic order
that women can't tolerate. And it's also a culture of hate that feminists have always
abroad because feminists have always developed international solidarity, a culture of peace,
which is in total contradiction with the values of the National Rally.
When the National Rally rejects claims that it will erode women's rights and says it's actually
seen its support among women's rise, I heard more about the demonstration from Catherine Norris
Trent, a senior correspondent for France 24. There were thousands of people protesting.
These demonstrations were in Paris. They were in other cities across France too,
and they had been called for by feminist organisations. More than 200 had called these protests to
warn about what they say are the dangers for women under a potential far right government.
They've been saying things about the right to get an abortion. Traditional views of lots of
members of the National Rally Marine Le Pen's party, they fear that it could lead to a regression
in terms of how women are viewed in French society. And does the National Rally hold these views?
Does it plan these kind of things if it gets into power? Well, the potential prime minister
for the National Rally, 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, put out a video explicitly denying that the
National Rally would be a threat to women's rights. He said that by fighting insecurity,
which a lot of people take to mean that, he's equating insecurity with immigration. He says that
by cracking down on that, they'll make the streets of France safer for women. But if you look at
recent events in Parliament, the right to an abortion was enshrined in the French Constitution,
and only around half of the National Rally's MPs actually voted for that. So some people are
pointing to that saying, look, they're saying they're in favour of women's rights. But when
it comes down to it, they're still very conservative. And yet despite that, the National Rally seems
to be winning over women voters. Why is that? I think that can be put down to the decline in
popularity of other parties in France, including Emmanuel Macron's own party and the traditional
left and right-wing parties. A lot of voters in France, men and women, are very fed up with the
traditional parties saying that they think the country's in decline, that there's been no progress.
So I think that ties into this general discontent and people perhaps hoping that the National Rally
might be some kind of alternative, something they haven't tried yet. Now the protest today is just
the latest against the far right. How does France feel going into these parliamentary elections?
Well, France is pretty on edge ahead of the first round of the elections, which are in one week's
time. There's a real sense that we don't know what's going to happen here, that we're in uncharted
territory. The polling is quite difficult because they're two round elections. So only the top
candor gets through the first round of voting and then they'll be head to heads or three-way runoffs
or even four-way runoffs in some circumscriptions. So it's not clear what the outcome could be.
The opinion polls do look like they're pointing towards the National Rally being the biggest
party in the French Parliament. Will it have enough to form a government? They said they'll only want
to do that if they've got an overall majority, it can actually govern or the country could be
plunged into months of political chaos with no party having a majority being that hung Parliament
and France basically being ungovernable. So there's a lot of nervousness in France right now.
Catherine Norris Trent of France 24. The Kenyan president William Ruto has said he is willing to
engage with the young people who've been protesting against planned tax rises.
His overture came a day after a second person died from injury sustained during Thursday's
Big Rally in the capital, Nairobi. In his first public comments, Mr Ruto praised the demonstrators
for raising their voices peacefully. But a protest organizer said he must respond publicly to their
demand for him to scrap the tax increase and accuse the police of brutalizing the protesters.
So what should we make of the president's intervention? I asked our Africa regional editor
Richard Kagoei in Nairobi. It wasn't quite anticipated because there's been lots of anxiety
in the air because you don't quite really know how this is going to end because the government
appeared probably because of its silence. They're going to just stand their position. And so this
coming from the president today and you know striking sort of like a reconciliation term,
it is a breath of fresh air because nobody knew really how this is going to pan out come
Tuesday when the young protesters at call for a national strike. How badly has the government been
rattled by the strength of the opposition? The government could be shaken to the core because
you know, these are protesters. They're young. They're not organized typically like those
protests that are led by trade unionist or politicians. So it's a bit difficult, especially
for the government to really tell where this is coming and where it's headed to. So a lot of people
would say the government might have been caught off guard when he came to this. And this olive branch
from the president, could it be a prelude to a U-turn on the tax rises or is it merely them
perhaps playing for time? Maybe playing for time because you know,
their constitutional timelines as to when the finance bill needs to be passed into law. So what
happened is when we had debate in Parliament and the bill went through its second reading. So a
committee was formed and they're supposed to look into some of the proposed amendments and come back
to Parliament on Tuesday where the bill is going to be debated and subjected to a final vote.
So I don't know what would be able to be accomplished between Sunday and Tuesday. I don't know how
this is going to be arranged. But a lot of our commentators say if it's rejected, it may not
necessarily plan the country into a financial or constitutional crisis. Richard Kugoey in Nairobi.
In a surprise move, the Grand Duke of Luxembourg is to step back from his duties and handover
powers to his son in October. However, Grand Duke Henri will retain his title.
Mr Booker reports,
When a crown passes on to a new generation, it normally happens through death or
abdication, but not so in Luxembourg. The tiny but rich European country has its own way of doing
things. There the Grand Duke appoints a Lyotnara placenton in effect a regent who takes over the
duties of the head of state. Prince Guillaume was always expected to get the title, but the timing
was a surprise. The Grand Duke is only 69 and in good health, despite an angioplasty more than 10
years ago. Like his father before him, he's likely to remain the formal head of state for some years
before handing over the throne and the Grand Duke title to his son.
Mr Booker, renting your home out to strangers can seem like something of a risk. How can you be
sure they'll look after it while you're away? But Sparrow thought for one homeowner in London who
returned to find his house transformed into a drug farm. Sophie Smith takes up the story.
Yeah, walked in and the first thing was the smell. It just smelled everything. All the weed,
all the human stuff. When Charles Reeves came home, he couldn't recognize his house. There were wires
dangling from holes in the ceiling and mounds of soil covering the floor, in one room reaching
almost a meter high. In another, there was an elaborate ventilation system. This is for maintaining
the right temperature to grow cannabis, something Mr Reeves's tenants have been doing while he was
away. This specifically, this was my bedroom. And now it's this.
The police have now seized more than 400 cannabis plants from the house. The Reeves family advertised
their property online before they moved abroad for work. An estate agent approached them, promising
a tenant family who was supposedly working for a city firm. But the tenants never paid any money
to Charles and his wife, Julia. And now they're going to have to spend thousands on fixing the
damage caused by the masses of soil, faulty wiring and general ruin of their property.
Experts say this is a crime that is on the rise in the UK. Alan Morgan is a leading expert witness
in criminal drug trials. He says this type of scam has a well-oiled setup. If you produce a
successful crop within, you know, a three-bedroom semi-detached house, you might yield a crop of
cannabis that's worth 30 to 40,000 pounds. So you offset that against the risk of detection.
They know that the legal system, if they stop paying the rent, they change the locks on the property,
they're not going to be evicted. The criminal, the legal process for eviction takes so long that
they have ample opportunity to complete the crop and then disappear. The Reeves family
expecting heavy losses, not just financially, but for the home that they have lost.
I did break down. Emotionally, it feels like my home has been defiled. This is the first real
home I ever had. Charles Reeves ending that report by Sophie Smith.
And that is all from us for now, but the Global News podcast will be back very soon.
This edition was mixed by Caroline Driscoll and produced by Alison Davis. Our editor's Karen Martin,
I'm Oliver Conway. Until next time, goodbye.
Hi, I'm former Wales International footballer Robert Earnshaw. I'm in Copper Bullets,
a new four-part series from Amazing Sport Stories. I'm exploring how my birth country, Zambia,
overcame the devastating loss of their national football team in 1993. Zambia has had its biggest
blow ever in the history of the country. I kept asking myself, how do we honour these people?
We had to raise from the ashes. Amazing Sport Stories from the BBC World Service.
Find it wherever you get your BBC podcasts.
